title: new pub rules coronavirus
story: Strict guidance tells pub and restaurant owners to prevent interaction between people in their venues - including clamping down on live music and ordering food and drinks through an app. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesGovernment guidance has laid out plans for pubs to reopen without transmission of coronavirus soaring. The PM said yesterday he was looking forward to the bustle toto Britains streets as he announced most businesses would be able to reopen. Mr Johnson told the House of Commons: We will also re-open restaurants and pubs.    But he warned: All hospitality indoors will be limited to table-service, and our guidance will encourage minimal staff and customer contact.The PM has refused to rule out bringing back a national lockdowncoronavirus cases start to rise again - so restaurants and pubs will have to follow strict rules to make sure people stick to social distancing. The days of crowding around bars waiting to order are over in a new normal of pub visits. Venues and being encouraged to be table-service only, and have guests order drinks and food through an app where possible.The guidance said: Indoor table service must be used where possible. Outdoor table service should also be encouraged though customers are permitted to stand outsidedistanced appropriately. The guidelines do not rule out ordering from the bar entirely, but warns venues should prevent customers from remaining at the bar or counter after ordering. Pubs have been told to encourage the use of contactless ordering from tables where available - for example, through an ordering app. The new rules mean people wont be able to hang out at the bar after theyve ordered, and will have to find a table or stand outside. All meetings indoors must only be with no more than two households at a time. Staff could also radio orders through to the kitchens to reduce movement by discouraging non-essential trips within venues. While both pubs and sports matches will have ed, Brits wont be able to do both at the same time. To discourage large groups of people coming together and yelling at TV screens or each other, broadcasts have been banned. Loud music will also be banned to stop people having to shout to be heard by their friends.The guidance says venues should ensure that steps are taken to avoid people needing to unduly raise their voices to each other. This includes but is not limited to, refraining from playing music or broadcasts that may encourage shouting, includingplayed at a volume that makes normal conversation dficult. This is because of the potential for increased risk of transmission, particularly from aerosol transmission.Live music and performances wont be allowed to continue under the new plans. The guidance warns venues they should not permit live performances, including drama, comedy and music, to take place in front of a live audience. Singing is a particular concerns - as droplets potentially carrying coronavirus could travel further as pub goers belt out their favourite songs.Dancing is also out, pubs have been told totake steps to prevent other close contact activities such as communal dancing. Venues are being encouraged to use disposable condiment packets where possible to limit the spread of germs via surfaces.Otherwise bottles need to be cleaned thoroughly after each use. Cutlery wont be laid out on tables unless people order food either. The guidance says venues should minimise customer self service of food, cutlery and condiments to reduce the risk of transmission. For example, providing cutlery and condiments only when food is served.The guidance says businesses should help the NHS Test and Trace system by keeping a registry of patrons contact details for at least  days in case of an outbreak. Venues are told to assistby keeping a temporary record of your customers and visitors for  days, in a way that is manageable for your business, and assist NHS Test and Trace with requests for that dataneeded. This could help contain clusters or outbreaks. Many businesses that take bookings already have systems for recording their customers and visitors – including restaurants, hotels, and hair salons. If you do not already do this, you should do so to help fight the virus.If there is an outbreak, it will allow contact tracers to easily find out who was in a pub or restaurant at a particular time. Pubs and restaurants will have to reduce the number of people in venues at any one time to allow for social distancing - but also to discourage public transport use. The new rules will ban groups of more than  people to form. That means evenvenues can have  people  metres apart they wont be able to.The guidance says: Evenit is possible to safely seat a number of people inside a venue, it may not be safe for them all to travel or enter that venue. Venues in nearby areas will have to work together to stagger arrival and departure times to avoid massive queues forming close to each other. Toilets which have been closed throughout the coronavirus crisis will reopen in pubs, restaurants and public places.But they will have to be subject to strict hygiene restrictions and extra cleaning. Venues are encouraged to use hand sanistiser where entering.And pubs are urged to use a limited entry approach to toilets inside venues with a one in one out rule.   To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast heatwave step national emergency
story: Forecasters have raised a heat health alert to amber for the East and West Midlands and told people to look out for the vulnerable, elderly and babies.The level three warning is triggered when temperatures are recorded that could have a “signicant effect on health”reached for two consecutive days and the intervening night.In the Midlands, conditions are forecast to see highs of C during the day and C at night.However,temperatures continue to rise the Met Office will place a National Emergency red warningIts website explains: “This is where a heatwave is so severe and or prolonged that its effects extend outside the health and social care system.”Adding: “At this level, illness and death may occur among the fit and healthy, and not just in high-risk groups.”It comes as medics warn that the heatwave will bring exceptionally high UV levels.Temperatures are tipped to rocket towards C tomorrow as the UK continues to bask in warm weather.Brits spent yesterday flocking to the country’s beaches, as they celebrated Boris Johnson’s reopening Britain’s pubs, bars and restaurants in July.But this has led to forecasters and medics to tell people to take extra precautions to stay safe in the sunMet Office meteorologist Alex Burkill said that UV levels will be reaching eight across many places and will be reaching nine across parts of Devon and Cornwall tomorrow.Thats about as high as it gets really in the UK. The sun is as strong as it gets at the moment because were so close to the solstice.Weve got peak sun strength, clear skies, plenty of sunshine - theyre the perfect ingredients for high UV.Mr Burkill advised anyone spending time outside on Wednesday and Thursday to protect themselves.Shoppers have also been warned they could be forced to spend extra time in the sun as a result of social-distancing measures.Dr Lynn Thomas, medical director at St John Ambulance, said: You could end up in the sun for longer than expected on what would normally be a quick journey, such as queuing to enter the supermarket, so you should be prepared to look after yourself and others.She added: Heat exhaustion and heatstroke are two of the most serious problems that can develop when the mercury soars but by being prepared you can spot the early warning signs, such as headache and dizziness.Public Health England has also issued a warning telling those with health conditions, coronavirus shielders, elderly people and very young children to be careful in the heat.Public health consultant Emer OConnell said vulnerable people should be checked up on regularly.The most important advice is to ensure they stay hydrated, keep cool and know how to keep their homes cool.You will need to do things dferently this year, for example keeping in touch by phone. If you need to provide direct care to someone at risk from hot weather, follow government guidance on how to do this safely, she said.

title: royal navy first ever crewless boat pacific 24
story: More than £million has been spent on the Pacic  boat and other self-operated crafts.The boats could help operations including search-and-rescue and drug raids in the Caribbean and Middle East. Boats could be sent on inidual missions or in groups, reaching speeds of up to  knots . In pursuit mode, it has a range of  nautical miles. The Pacic  has been used in sea boat operations from Royal Navy warships for more than  years.But the new drone version of the boat could provide a more streamlined way of carrying out its wide range of operations - and even open up some new types of missions.The boats will be controlled from a parent ship, such as a frigate or destroyer.Defence Minister Jeremy Quin said: Commencing the trials of the crewless Pacic  boat is an important stepping stone in the Royal Navys development of its autonomous capability to ensure our fleet remains at the forefront of military innovation and technology, ready to meet the evolving threats of modern warfare.The crewless Pacic  is sponsored by NavyX, the specialist wing of the Royal Navy which trials cutting-edge technology for use on the front line.The team has worked in partnership with BAE Systems, which builds the Pacic  in Portsmouth, to commission the new boat.A prototype, controlled from the frigate HMS Argyll, debuted at the DSEI defence technology showcase in London last September, since when BAE and the Navy have pressed ahead with a working model fit for the front line.The vessels control system and sensors mean a sailor should be able to give the unmanned craft generic tasking, and the boat will decide for itself how it carries out that task.Lieutenant Commander Rob Manson of the NavyX team said: The autonomous nature of this craft adds huge capability and flexibility.Brooke Hoskins, Products and Training Services Director at BAE Systems said: We are proud to support the Royal Navys autonomous requirements, which includes increasing its operational effectiveness whilst reducing the burden on, or threat to, its sailors.Trials with the new craft begin this month, followed by trials with a Royal Navy warship later this year which should determine whether the UK invests in a fleet of such craft or just a few for specic missions.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: russian oligarch 360m superyacht docks south of france
story: Andrey Melnichenko wowed onlookers as he pulled his enormous ft-long futuristic vessel with luxurious on-board pool and extravagant lounge decks into port. The impressive vessel, which comes complete with eight decks and masts that are almost ft tall, is the ninth largest yacht in the world and took four years to build.The luxury yacht features multiple dining rooms and several balconies which stylishly open up on the side of the hull.The yacht is powered by a hybrid diesel-electric package with controllable pitch propellers.Up to  lucky guests can be accommodated on the mega-boat, hosted by a crew of , according to reports.Aside from the opulent lounge, the superyacht boasts floor-to-ceiling windows, a combination of leather and wood furniture and a rotating bed.It also has free-floating spiral staircases and three masts that are taller than Big Ben and stretch up from the extraordinary wedge-shaped boat hull.One of the masts is accessible from the inside, but the crew dont need to climb them – the boat’s sails unfurl at the touch of a button.The masts are technical masterpieces, and can rotate to make the most of the wind when out at sea.The boat was also designed with bomb-proof glass windows and an owners cabin which is larger than most apartments in London or New York.The high-gloss ship is able to whir across the waves at speeds of up to .knots .The ship also boasts a garage fit for four vehicles and a submarine, as well as a helipad on the bow.Melnichenko named his superyacht A because in order for the vessel to be listed first in shipping registers.The total sail area is equal to that of half a football pitch, with two double-decker buses able to be hung from the masts.The Russian industrialists newest yacht also includes rotating masts that were built by Magma Strustures at Trafalgar Wharf, Portsmouth.The Russian billionaire is notorious for his extravagant lestyle.Alongside his two astonishing superyachts, the billionaire owns a customised Boeing  private jet, a villa in the French Riviera, a penthouse in New York and an estate near Ascot, England. He married his model we Aleksandra in an opulent ceremony in the South of France with singers Whitney Houston and Christina Aguilera leading the after-party.Melnichenko, , is also the father of a young daughter and has an estimated net worth of around £.billion, making him the th richest person in Russia and the th wealthiest person in the world.The Russian made his billions founding the fertiliser producer EuroChem, coal producer Suek, and power generator SGK. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: stay half in half out of lockdown well be happier
story: LOCKDOWN is pretty much over. The Prime Minister announced that we were at last allowed out of our Great British Hibernation.We can go to the pub, buy useless tat in shops and queue up for plaster lawn ornaments from garden centres. We can have the in-laws round to visit! Yoot!⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBoris says that his decision was made on good scientic advice. Hmm, maybe. It is true that the infection rate for Covid has been dropping rapidly for some time. But it’s still there, still hanging around with mischief on its mind. All it takes is one person in a gathering of  or  at some pizza joint and that infection rate will be up again quickly enough.In some of the countries that have released their people from lockdown, a second spike has occurred.In Germany the famous “R” rate for infection is well above the dreaded one. South Korea and Spain have seen new outbreaks, too.But the truth is Boris didn’t have much of an option. The public is bored stf and the economy is wrecked.I suspect the decision was arrived at on those grounds, rather than strictly on the science. Everyone wants to go out and spend money. I am not sure why they do.  There were good things about lockdown — and it taught us one or two truths about ourselves.It was a pleasure to hear the birds singing, for example. A real delight to see the roads free from traffic. The skies are full of swts and swallows instead of the incessant airline flights. The quality of the air we breathe improved hugely as a result. So did the water quality of rivers and streams.We went out much, much less. As a consequence, many people saved an awful lot of money because they weren’t wasting it on buying rubbish from shops.People learned to cook — and ate home-prepared meals with their families. The truth is, in normal times, we eat out far more often than is good for us, financially or otherwise. And we shopped locally — the corner stores did a roaring trade — and less often, thus saving carbon emissions.Employers discovered that people could work from home perfectly well. Hopefully this will persuade some to scale back their offices and give people the chance to work from home.Imagine how many homes could be created from disused offices! We wouldn’t have to pave over half the country to sort out our housing crisis. Imagine cutting out the daily commute for ever!We didn’t have to hug people. Indeed, we were barred by law from hugging people. Or kissing them on the bloody cheek, like everyone in the media world does. That, by itself, was a huge bonus for me.My wish is that we take some of that stuff from lockdown and make it the new normal. Live at a quieter, gentler pace. Continue to eat at home — and support our local corner shops. Use the car less. Spend less money on a whole load of b******s we don’t really need. Use aeroplanes not at all, preferably. Right now, the Government has given us licence to go out and do stuff.Here’s my plea. Let’s do a bit less stuff than we used to. Let’s remain kind of half in and half out of lockdown. Whether Covid is still around or not. We’ll end up happier as a result.ONE thing Captain Tom showed us, as he walked around his garden as he approached the age of , is that it’s never too late to make a dference.Bob Dylan is just a young whippersnapper by Tom’s standards.But at the age of  he has just made his finest album in at least three decades, and probably more. Rough And Rowdy Ways is a joy to listen to – and I’d given up on the bloke in the s.If I ever reach  I intend to make a grime album with Rihanna. Get your orders in now.The United Nations has decided to give them to Mauritius. That’s because the islands are nearer Mauritius than they are to the UK. On that basis we could have a good claim to owning Belgium. The islands are important to the UK militarily. And we should keep them. The UN has given us deadlines to hand them over to a country that never owned them. What we should do instead is leave the crooked UN.EXCLUDED from the Government’s loosening of lockdown are Britain’s vibrant community of werewolves and vampires.“It is all very well biting someone’s neck, or ripping their lungs out while howling loudly,” a scientist advising the Government probably said. “But when they do this there is the risk that the virus could be passed on via droplets from the creature’s mouth. Or indeed paws – werewolves do not have a good record of using hand-sanitiser.”By contrast, zombies were praised for their social-distancing technique. “Whenever you see them they are always walking two metres apart with their hands outstretched and bits of flesh falling off their faces,” the same scientist probably added.A spokesman for the National Association of Lycanthropescommented: “This is typical of the prejudice we werewolves face and amounts to discrimination. Actually, I thought I had the virus a few weeks ago. Nasty cough and so on.“But I’m all right nooooowwwwwwooooo.”THE day after the woke ninnies at Warners withdrew the great Hollywood film Gone With The Wind because of “race issues”, guess what happened  Yup, it became the No bestselling film on Amazon. Better still, it reached No in the AppleiTunes chart for TV and film. Not bad for a movie made more than  years ago, huh I suppose it could have been “progressives” buying the film so that they would have something to be outraged about. Or maybe the Ku Klux Klan Film Club has a bigger membership than we thought.More likely though is that people loathe censorship. They don’t like being told what they can and can’t watch. Truth be told it hasn’t been for a good  years. And the process accelerated under Magic Grandpa and his front bench of mouth-breathing dingbats. Now it’s the well-orf who support Labour. And the poor who vote Conservative. But there aren’t enough people called Olly and Poppy in the country, which is why Labour hasn’t won an election for  years. Unless it reconnects with the people it was set up to support, the working class, it won’t win one for another few decades either.A SOCIAL media site had a big hit when it asked people to reveal things they regretted about getting married. The site, Whisper, was inundated with replies. Most were kind of: “I just wish I hadn’t married the fat bastard, full stop.”But some wished they’d had a fling with someone of the same sex first, or felt aggrieved they hadn’t checked out the in-laws first. That was quite a big issue. title: benidorm new normal holiday sanitiser beaches
story: In C Benidorm I found that old ritual of claiming your spot on the beach with your towel is no more.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesTo bagsy your well-earned piece of golden sand you’ll soon have to make a booking by app.And, along with cheap booze and Full English, the bars in the Costa Blanca resort are serving up temperature tests, shoe disinfectant and sanitiser stations.Desperate for theof British tourists, Benidorm has carved up Poniente and Levante beaches into , ft x ft taped off plots — with a maximum of four people allowed in each square.There’ll even be an area reserved for the over-s marked in green.One local moaned that under the new system you can either pay £ and get a sunbed and sunshade or “get put in a square like a pig”.But from a beach square she shared with three friends, student Paula Aquado, , told me: “It feels safe and it’s great to be on the beach again despite the restrictions.”Police patrol the beaches to check on social distancing. Monitors at beach entrances count the number of people entering and douse the walkways with disinfectant.I had taken one of the first Ryanair flights to Alicante from Britain this week as Spain threw open its doors to UK tourists.Early morning flyers formed long, socially-distanced queues at security for flights to Portugal, Spain, Bulgaria and Hungary. In face masks and using sanitiser dispensers dotted around Luton airport, travellers kept their two-metre distance by following stickers on the ground.Queuing with a friend, a British plasterer in his s told me: “We decided on impulse to book the flight because we’re bored of lockdown. We haven’t even booked a hotel in Benidorm but at least you can get a beer in a bar there.”On board the half-full flight, ­passengers were ordered to wear facemasks at all times.A trolley service by masked cabin staff sold beers, wines, spirits and snacks with payment by card only.At Alicante airport, border guards checked passports behind perspex screens.Passengers had to fill out contact tracing forms giving their home and holiday addresses, email and phone number before passing through thermal imaging cameras.At arrivals the Cooper family had a tearful reunion. Mum Kirsty, an expat translator, wept as she greeted sons Jayden, , and Jack, , who had been unable to fly back from the UK during lockdown.Kirsty, , said: “I’m just happy to see my boys again.”At Benidorm’s four-star Los Alamos Hotel, I was greeted by mask-wearing reception staff who asked me to disinfect my hands.Guests — who must wear a mask or maintain a .m distance — are required to sign an indemnity form promising that they will abide by social distancing rules or face being kicked out of the hotel.A sticker taped to my room door and its lintel said: “Room cleaned and sealed for your protection.”Guests trooped down to breakfast in masks and were given a dollop of hand sanitiser before joining a socially-distanced queue for grub.The all-you-can-eat breakfast buffet was no more. Staff cooked up omelettes and serve cereal to order.The masks come off at your table so you can eat. In the bar there were virtual menus accessed by phone app.Manager Maria Sanchez, , said: “We’re ready to welcome our British friends back.”Many bars and restaurants remained shuttered before the expected influx of Brits next month.At the Kai Beach bar, drinkers’ temperatures were taken before entering.Then shoes were sanitised and hands doused with gel.At Jumping Jacks, a handful of expats sipped lager on tables m apart after sanitising their hands.Engineer Dale Oldfield, , from Rochdale, who arrived in Benidorm where he has a caravan on Monday, said: “After months of lockdown, it’s great to have a beer in a pub and a steak in restaurant.”Benidorm lures more than a million British holidaymakers a year —  per cent of its foreign visitors. title: school return pupil bubble cap doubles
story: Under current rules, class numbers are capped at  and social distancing measures leave heads with a logistical nightmare requiring double the teaching space.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBut from the autumn primary school pupils will not be required to keep apart from others in their own “protective bubble”, just stay away from other groups.One of the first schools to fully reopen in Britain has made passionate calls for others to follow suit — and urged “isive” unions to get on board.St Paul’s CofE Primary in Swanley, Kent, welcomed back nearly all of its  children on Monday thanks to shrewd social distancing and hygiene measures.The school’s chiefs put a marquee in their playing field to create extra space — and supplied portaloos and mobile hand washing facilities to keep kids safe.Dferent classes are kept apart with their own inidual entrances and exits. And eager children have ed straight back into lessons under strict social distancing rules without hassle.Thecomes in spite of teaching unions pouring scorn over moves to get all kids safely back in class by September.Headteacher Ben Hulme said tonight: “Schools like us have shown it can be done safely for both children and staff.“This is a time when unions, schools and headteachers should all be pulling together to get children back in class. To be isive makes it really dficult to get back to some safe normality.“There have been many reports about how lockdown has affected children’s mental health and emotional wellbeing — and how there’s potential for damage to be donewe don’t move quickly. That really spurred us on to get something together — and it’s working very well.“We’re really pleased to be back and I’d encourage other schools to do the samethey can.”Under the new plans, the Government aims to form “year group bubbles” in secondary schools.This would stop pupils mingling with teenagers from other year groups, while allowing classes toto their normal size.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson hailed St Paul’s safe and swt— and called on others to take “full advantage” of the chance to open again.He told The Sun: “We have given primary schools the flexibility to bring back more children — where they can do so within our protective measures — and it’s fantastic to see some schools taking full advantage of that to maximise their capacity and invite back all pupils.”Anne Longfield, the Children’s Commissioner for England, heaped praise on St Paul’s — and urged other schools to follow its lead.She said: “This is a real achievement and great to see teachers working with parents to get the whole school open safely before the summer break.”The Government originally ­pledged to get all primary schools back in action for at least a month before June . But ministers had to ditch the plans over fears that the target would not be met.Militant unions have been accused of playing politics and stopping kids ing to class, instead of putting their welfare first.Department for Education data revealed , pupils were in class last month — down from . million on a normal school day.Latest figures show approximately . million attended school last Thursday — . per cent of pupils who normally attend." rel"noreferrer noopener"Boris Johnson told MPs yesterday that education would restart fully at the start of autumn term.It was welcome news for millions of parents who have endured three months of lockdown — many juggling full-time jobs with childcare and home-schooling. Secondary schools in England have been allowed to reopen for Years ,  and  since June .Nursery and pre-school children, plus pupils in Reception, Year  and Year , started toon June .But not all schools have reopened fully. Some do not have the staff and others do not have the space.Current government guidance for schools does not require kids to socially distance within their bubble, but many schools are ignoring the advice, insisting on all pupils remaining two-metres apart.The rules planned for September would make clear that social distancing would not be required within bubbles.Instead, kids will be encouraged to limit contact with each other.Its Headmaster Ben Hulme used his imagination, created extra space on the school field and put other hygiene measures in place.Now, to the delight of parents, almost all his pupils started back on Monday. And that’s with the two-metre rule.Yes, it’s easier with a small school. But his determination to do what is right by the children made the real dference.Contrast that with the union militants and council leaders of the Left. Although the Government could have done better in prioritising education, the wrecking crew have revelled in confronting and defying the Tories, blocking efforts to reopen fully.Even now, the PM’s announcement that schools must open in September is branded “pure fantasy” by one union.We do not yet know the true cost to our children’s education, le chances and health from this failure of will.The unions have betrayed our kids and tarnished the image of the teachers they represent and who would love to get back to the classroom.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ahmaud arbery travis greg mcmichael georgia indicted
story: The slaying of Arbery has been one of several racially-charged cases that have rocked the country in recent months.Here is more on the Georgia shooting that took place on February .Arbery, who was , was murdered when Greg McMichael and son Travis armed themselves and pursued the Black man running in their Brunswick neighborhood.Greg McMichael told police he suspected Arbery was a burglar and that Arbery attacked his son.The father claied he and his son had said: Stop, stop, we want to talk to you.Shots were fired and Arbery fell to the street in the Satilla Shores neighborhood.Father and son were not arrested until  days after shooting - and several days after a video of the fatal confrontation went viral.Disturbing video shows Arbery harassed by cops for sitting in his car two years before his death.A grand jury indicted father and son on felony murder and malice charges, a prosecutor announced Wednesday.“This is another positive step, another great step for finding justice for Ahmaud, for finding justice for this family and the community beyond,” said prosecutor Joyette Holmes.A statewide judicial emergency had previously been declared due to the coronavirus pandemic, but Holmes said they were able to call in a grand jury that had been imed prior to the emergency.Guidelines were followed and jurors were provided hand sanitizer. Social distancing mandates were also observed.The Arbery family did not know when the next steps would be taken after a probable cause hearing was held earlier this month.“The family was ecstatic to hear that it had happened this morning, said Holmes.When a person is indicted, he is given formal notice that it is believed that he committed a crime, according to the Department of Justice.The indictment contains the basic information that informs the person of the charges against him.The grand jury has found that there is enough evidence to pursue a criminal case against Travis and Greg McMichael.William Roddie Bryan, who recorded the deadly encounter, was also indicted on felony murder and malice charges.It was after Bryans cellphone footage leaked online that the McMichaels were arrested.Bryan was busted last month after he tried “to confine and detain” Arbery without legal authority by “utilizing his vehicle on multiple occasions” before Arbery was shot, according to authorities.Prosecutors believe that Bryan played a major role in Arberys death by hitting him with the side of his vehicle.All three defendants are also charged with two counts of aggravated assault and one count each of  imprisonment and criminal attempt to commit  imprisonment.Bryans lawyer said his client has committed no crime and has cooperated with law enforcement officers from the beginning.“We welcome the action of the grand jury today, said Kevin Gough.While we disagree with it, it’s an important step in the process to moving this case closer to the speedy trial that Roddie has demanded.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: music britain collapsing covid 19
story: And now I’m scratching my head wondering how cinemas are able to welcome visitors before we’ve worked out how to listen to music together.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesLive music is vital, not just for fuelling our dreams but for the reality of our economy, too.The live music sector is expecting to suffer £million in losses this year, which is  per cent of its annual contribution to the UK economy.From arena concerts to your local pub singer, ALL live music has been silenced.But the Government doesn’t seem to be taking it seriously, with music way down the list of priorities and no date in the diary for when we will be able to go to a gig again.We can’t afford to take our music scene for granted.Since the birth of rock ’n’ roll, Britain has dominated global tastes in pop music.Part of The Beatles’ legacy is that they transformed the British record business from a cottage industry into a global phenomenon.When they signed to Parlophone, early in the Sixties, one man and his secretary ran the entire label.George Martin signed the band, produced, manufactured and promoted their early records and, over the brief course of the band’s existence, saw the whole thing go through the roof.It was comparable to the dotcom boom or internet shopping.Many now see the Rolling Stones as the greatest band to come out of that era for the way they have managed to continue playing to vast new audiences  years later.But the Sixties was just the start of it. The Seventies brought Led Zeppelin and countless rock bands, it gave us heavy metal and punk and Joy Division pretty much all at the same time.The biggest-selling album of the Eighties, Michael Jackson’s Thriller, was actually written by a bloke from Hull, while British greats as erse as Duran Duran and The Smiths ruled the waves.In the Cool Britannia of the Nineties, when Britpop was ringing out of radio networks worldwide, even American stars such as Madonna sought help from British producers such as Nellee Hooper and William Orbit.Then there were the Spice Girls. And Coldplay. Now we’ve got Ed Sheeran and Adele. And it doesn’t stop with artists. Love him or hate him, Simon Cowell’s TV programmes are another British global music phenomenon.But it’s live music where Britain really dominates today. Glastonbury should be taking place this weekend.I’ve played at just about every major festival on the planet, from Coachella in the US to Fuji Rock in Japan, but there is nowhere to touch Glastonbury.It is, quite simply, the greatest show on earth There is a massive ripple effect from Glastonbury. It sets a very high bar for the other  — that’s  — festivals that happen throughout the UK every single summer.And the same crews who build the stages, operate the sound systems, put up the fences and supply the bogs for Glasto are busy for the rest of the summer at other events.Now the independent festival sector is at risk of collapse thanks to the Covid shutdown.Last month, the Association of Independent Festivals , which represents  festivals in the UK, reported that  per cent of its members were facing costs that could ruin their businesses and . per cent were uninsured for Covid- related cancellations.Most of my time these days is spent planning and organising The Big Feastival, which was due to take place here on my farm in Oxfordshire this August Bank Holiday weekend.Of course I’m devastated it won’t be going ahead, but the really sad thing is that it looks like no one is going to hear any live music, new or old this summer.That’s a tragedy for the musicians who rely on gigging to make a living — as well as all the other people whose income relies on live music.The Musicians’ Union says its members have lost more than £million in income during the lockdown. Remember, that most musicians just scrape by at the best of times.Big stars are bigger than ever before, but they are the exception not the rule. When Adele releases another record there is a danger she will become so massive she will collapse into a black hole.But now bands need an audience to play to and also financial support, which used to come from record companies but now is hard to find.Records, or downloads, are basically free these days, so live shows are the only real way to make money.In the same way restaurants were already struggling before lockdown, many of Britain’s smaller live music venues were struggling too.So most of the places I played in the early days with Blur have already dis- appeared. They need to be able to open their doors again, as do festivals.It has to be possible to find a way. Just as with pubs, restaurants and cinemas, you could limit the number of people allowed into a venue.Perhaps more gigs could be seated to ensure social distancing. Not quite the same, but better than nothing.As far as the rest of the planet is concerned, Britain is represented pretty much by the Royal Family, football and music.We must keep our festival circuit alive and nurture new artists.That means we urgently have to find a way for music to be played to a live audience, evenit’s only a small one — so that we can keep meaning something to the rest of the world.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: unions betrayed our kids
story: Its Headmaster Ben Hulme used his imagination, created extra space on the school field and put other hygiene measures in place.Now, to the delight of parents, almost all his pupils started back on Monday. And that’s with the two-metre rule.Yes, it’s easier with a small school. But his determination to do what is right by the children made the real dference.Contrast that with the union militants and council leaders of the Left. Although the Government could have done better in prioritising education, the wrecking crew have revelled in  confronting and defying the Tories, blocking efforts to reopen fully.Even now, the PM’s announcement that schools must open in September is branded “pure fantasy” by one union.We do not yet know the true cost to our children’s education, le chances and health from this failure of will. The unions have betrayed our kids and tarnished the image of the teachers they represent and who would love to get back to the classroom.PUBS with no music, singing, dancing or shouting  That’s just a library with more beer and no books.And how about visor-clad hairdressers snipping in enforced silence, with no gossip or radio It all sounds like a sci-fi dystopia of Britain. But this is the Government’s vision for our summer as it tries to save businesses while keeping us safe.To which we say: Well, good luck with that. We understand the reasoning. The scientists say all these activities pass on Covid in the breath. And they are desperate to avoid a new surge in cases.Some might see little point in a pub with the le sucked out of it. But we must use them or lose them.From July , support your local. Consider it your solemn duty.THE survey saying a quarter of furloughed workers will lose their jobs is horrying.Nine million are being kept afloat by the bailout. But that ruinous cost will end. At which point more than two million will be added to the dole queue.That will be a bitter blow for many who have enjoyed the lockdown — some packing the beaches yesterday on what would ordinarily be a working day.The bailouts’ end in October spells devastation in particular for the young and low-paid. And it falls to Chancellor Rishi Sunak to recreate the jobs boom of the last decade.At least, post-Brexit, he will have even more tools with which to do it.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: quarter of furloughed workers likely to lose their jobs
story: Reductions to the amount being spent on the scheme will start in September.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesA survey of , businesses on behalf of London-based lender MarketFinance Ltd found nearly  per cent planned job cuts.The poll also found that  per cent of companies plan to bring back up to half of their furloughed staff next month.The government s coronavirus job retention scheme was announced in March  allowing furloughed employees to claim  per cent of their wages up to £, a month. From August employers will have to contribute to wages, initially by paying national insurance and pension contributions.Nine million are being kept afloat by the bailout. But that ruinous cost will end. At which point more than two million will be added to the dole queue.That will be a bitter blow for many who have enjoyed the lockdown — some packing the beaches yesterday on what would ordinarily be a working day.The bailouts’ end in October spells devastation in particular for the young and low-paid. And it falls to Chancellor Rishi Sunak to recreate the jobs boom of the last decade.At least, post-Brexit, he will have even more tools with which to do it.From September they will have to pay those contributions plus  per cent of salaries.Then from October they will have to pay those contributions plus  per cent of salaries.Chancellor Rishi Sunak has extended the scheme until the end of October. title: leicester city demarai gray girlfriend mansion raid worcestershire
story: The raid at the Premier League players mansion in Worcestershire was part of a six-month crime spree.Grays girlfriend Emma Hickman was confronted by balaclava-clad intruders, one wielding a machete, as she lay in bed naked with the couples six-week-old child.She was so terried she later moved out.Aaron Jones, , and Tyler Greenway, , were both found guilty of conspiracy to rob following a trial.Jones was also convicted of conspiracy to possess a firearm.They had both previously admitted conspiracy to burgle and theft.Nicholas Rothero, , and his son Cory Rothero, , had both previouslyadmitted conspiracy to rob, steal, burgle, and conspiracy to possess afirearm.Darren Sadler, , of Bartley Green, had previously pleaded guilty to conspiracy to rob.Jones was jailed for  years, Nicholas Rothero for  years andSaddler for four years.Saddlers sentence was ordered to run consecutively to a term of tenyears and eight months he is already serving for robbery.Both Cory Rothero and Greenway were each sentenced to  years in ayoung offenders institution.Michael Duck QC, prosecuting, told Birmingham Crown Court: Thedefendants are a group of organised criminals. Between October and April  they committed a series of armed robberies andburglaries at commercial and residential premises.He said they used serious violence which escalated over time.They went to signicant s to disguise themselves and chosevulnerable targets such as small stores which had a limited amount ofstaff, Mr Duck said.They arrived in stolen cars which were used to get away at the fastest speed possible.Mr Duck said: They arrived mob-handed, conspicuously armed withknives, making a lot of noise and terrying those they encountered.They raided safes and cashpoints.The first shop targeted was a One Stop in Bristol Road North,Northfield, on October . They made off with £, after wielding ahammer, kne and crow bar and workers to the back of the premises.The gang also netted arond £, after terrorising two employees atthe Barnt Green Inn pubb and snatched £,-worth of mobiles from aphone shop where staff were threatened.Saddler was arrested following a struggle with police after a raid ona Car Phone Warehouse.But that did not deter the close knit team, who attacked a TescoExpress in Northfield armed themselves with weapons including a gun.Describing the attack on the home of the -year-old footballer, Mr Duck said there was evidence that the premises had been deliberately targeted.He went on: The male occupant of the premises was not there that day.He was at work.Members of the gang, armed with knives, parked alongside a hedgebefore breaking in.They stayed briefly downstairs before going upstairs where -year-oldMiss Hickman was trying to catch up on some sleep.She was woken from her sleep and greeted by the sight of a man whowas obviously masked and carrying a large black kne, Mr Duck said.The intruder, Nicholas Rothero, was then joined by Jones and CoryRothero and one of them picked up a gold kne from the side of the bedwhich her partner used to open parcels and envelopes.She was completely trapped and confined with the confines of her bedroom.Mr Duck said they knew something about her boyfriend and expressedsurprise he was not there.During the trial, Miss Hickman said the raiders demanded jewellery and money.She said she had been petried and they had accused her partner ofbeing a gangbanger and demanded to know when he was coming back.They snatched her Rolex and told her the footballer could fork out foranother one.When she told them her mother was on the way, the men told her hershed get hurt when she arrived.The raiders also took keys to Gray’s Mercedes only to discover it wasnot on the driveway before they fled with £,-worth of cash andjewellery in a stolen car.Passing sentence, Judge Richard Bond said the offences were executedruthlessly and with a real degree of success.He said that on two occasions guns were used to instil fear intovictims so they would co-operate.A feature is the professionalism in the way the offending was carriedout, he told the gangsters.Full disguises were used by the offenders to cause victims to beintimidated when confronted by you.Victims were made to feel scared and helpless and on some occasionsfearful for their lives.Your professionalism was also demonstrated by the speed of the offences.You targeted vulnerable premises. The sophistication of youroffending was also demonstrated by the wearing of gloves to ensurethat finger prints were not left behind.CCTV shows on several occasions members of staff cowering in terrorduring the course of robberies.Referring to the attack on Grays home, he said: This property wasdeliberately targeted by you because of who lived there.Jones made inquiries on the internet about the person.You believed there would be rich pickings at the property. You weretargeting high-value goods.Miss Hickman could not have been more vulnerable in her own home.She bravely gave evidence and it is dficult to forget the obviousterror she felt when confronted by three masked men in her bedroom.She was traumatised by what happened and has moved out of the house.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailLoud football match screenings or music, dance floors, ketchup bottles and even sheltering from the rain are set to be banned when Englandaposs pubs reopen on July . Government guidance today shows many toilets will need to be one-in, one-out and bar staff hidden behind screens to prevent the spread of the virus. Pubs will be told to keep lists of everyone who comes in for  days in case there is an outbreak - with more outdoor seats and tape to mark distance on the floor. Bar managers will be told to work with their rivals on the same street to make sure they stagger their opening times. And punters will be warned they canapost shelter insidea rainstorm - otherwise they could cause an outbreak. We knew a lot of the restrictions already. For example, you can only sit indoors with one other household - socially distanced. If youaposre in the beer garden, you can sit in a group of up to six - socially distanced - or in a group of two households of any size. Now the governmentaposs guidance shows just how dferent the new normal will be to le before. Here are  key ways itaposll change your experience of the pub. . Loud music or broadcasts will be banned to stop people shouting  Loud music or loud broadcasts like football will be banned to stop people shouting at each other. The guidance says all venues should ensure that steps are taken to avoid people needing to unduly raise their voices to each other. This includes, but is not limited to, refraining from playing music or broadcasts that may encourage shouting, includingplayed at a volume that makes normal conversation dficult. This is because of the potential for increased risk of transmission, particularly from aerosol transmission. It also says loud background music, communal dancing, group singing or chanting should be prevented. . Live music, comedy and dance floors will be banned  The guidance says venues should not permit live performances, including drama, comedy and music, to take place in front of a live audience. This is to stop aerosol transmission - from either the performer or their audience. Theatres are likewise allowed to open but onlythey donapost put on a live show. Dance floors in pubs and bars are also banned. You should take steps to prevent close contact activities, such as communal dancing, the guidance says. . Ketchup bottles and cutlery are banished from tables  The guidance says pubs and restaurants should provide cutlery and condiments only when food is served. And the days of the communal ketchup or mayonnaise bottle are numbered - as pubs and restaurants should provide only disposable condiments. Communal bottles are allowed but onlythey are cleaned after every single use. . Everyone has to give their name to staff - and itaposs kept for  days  All pubs, bars, restaurants and more are being told to assist with the NHS Test and Trace programme. That means keeping a temporary record of your customers and visitors for  days. The guidance doesnapost say how this should be done but lists visitor books or bookings records. Pubs will need to assist NHS Test and Trace with requests for that dataneeded in order to contain clusters or outbreaks. . Bar staff will stand behind screens  The guidance recommends using screens or barriers to separate workers from each other, and from customers at points of service. That could mean bar staff serving from behind a perspex screen to avoid transmission. Staff are also asked to use back-to-back or side-to-side working possible. And staff rotas will need to be redrawn so each person only has contact with a fixed number of others on their team. Tables will be spaced further apart and floor tape or paint will be used to mark areas to help people comply with social distancing. They should be two metres apart - or one metrethere is risk mitigation in place like screens, back-to-back seating or face coverings. . Some toilets will be one-in, one-out  The guidance recommends one way flow systems to stop people bunching up - such as using one door as an entry and one as an exit. Pubs should also arrange one-way travel routes between transport hubs and venues, it says. But thataposs a problem when it comes to pub toilets, many of which are cramped with narrow entrances. On toilets, the guidance urges pubs to use a limited entry approach, with one in, one out. . Youaposll get more outdoor seats, table service - and use apps to order your drinks  Pubs are being encouraged to put in more outdoor seats - with changes coming down the track to let them use car parks as beer gardens. Outdoor table service should also be encouraged, the guidance says - and table service should be followed as a rule to stop people queues. Where bar or counter service is unavoidable, people should be stopped from staying at the bar or counter after ordering, or leaning on it. Pubs are also told to encourage use of contactless ordering from tables where available - for example, through an ordering app. . Staff could radio food orders through to the kitchen Staff are told to reduce movement by discouraging non-essential trips within venues. That could mean restricting access to some areas, encouraging use of radios, telephones or other electronic devices when sending orders from service areas to kitchens, where permitted. The radios would have to be cleaned between use. . Youaposll be banned from propping up the bar - or sheltering from the rain  Pubs are warned they have to plan for keeping the -metre or aposone metre plusapos rules eventhere is a thunderstorm. They need to be clear that customers cannot seek shelter indoors unless social distancing can be maintained. . Indoor spaces will have to be massively below capacity  Sitting indoors will be allowed - but numbers are strictly limited. New coronavirus laws from July  in England will make it illegal for groups of more than  people to form. Pubs, restaurants, cinemas and other venues will be exempt from the aposgroup of apos law, which exists mainly to prevent things like raves. But even so, the guidance warns pubs may have to lower capacity even further than it would bethey had all tables two metres apart. The guidance explains: Evenit is possible to safely seat a number of people inside a venue, it may not be safe for them all to travel or enter that venue. . Youaposll see this sign in the window  Pubs should work with their customers to tell them about the restrictions on gatherings. That means not gathering indoors with more than one other household. And it means not gathering outdoors with more than either one other household, or six people in total from any number of households. In , firms should also display a notication in a prominent place to show a risk assessment has been carried out and theyaposre following the rules. A picture of the notice is above. . Nearby pubs must work together to open at dferent times Inidual businesses should consider the cumulative impact of many venues re-opening in a small area. This means working with local authorities, neighbouring businesses and travel operators to assess this risk and applying additional mitigations. This might have to include staggering entry times with other venues and taking steps to avoid queues building up in surrounding areas.

story: NewsPubs could serve people booze in the street under new lawsMinisters will set out plans to simply the licensing process and cut red tape in England this summer through the new Business and Planning billShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political EditorOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  JUN NewsDrinking outdoors could become the new normal" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email More pubs, restaurants and cafes will be allowed to serve customers outside under new laws introduced on Thursday to help the economy bounce back from coronavirus.Ministers will set out plans to simply the licensing process and cut red tape in England this summer through the new Business and Planning bill. But the Government faces fresh calls from unions to make sure that hospitality workers are protected against the deadly disease - and the economic fallout from the crisis. Boris Johnson has set out plans to reopen pubs, restaurants and other venues from July  after three months of lockdown have pushed many to the brink of collapse.Hospitality sector chiefs have warned that thousands of jobs have already been lost and hundreds of businesses have gone bust. Under the plans, councils across the country will be able to pedestrianise areas and relax rules so outdoor markets, pop-up car-boot sales and summer fairs will not need a planning application. There will also be changes to licensing laws to allow many more pubs, bars and restaurants sell alcohol to drink where, making social distancing easier. Other changes include allowing hospitality venues to use car parks and terraces as dining and drinking areas so customers can enjoy their drinks and food outside. The measures, which will be rushed through the Commons, come into force before they reopen next week.  The Government yesterday published detailed guidance for businesses including pubs, hairdressers, hotels and indoor attractions on keeping venues safe for workers and visitors before July . One plan that looks to have been put on the back burner by Downing Street is mooted proposals to extend Sunday trading hours following reports in theof a mounting Tory revolt.No.  said only that Sunday trading proposals were under review after Labour suggested the changes were not in the so-called Covid Bill.Reports claimed that Mr Johnson had been warned in a letter from backbenchers that at least  Conservative MPs were prepared to join forces with Labour to defeat any attempt to loosen Sunday trading hours.

Robert Jenrick tonight agreed to release correspondence relating to the Westferry Printworks development, planned by millionaire mogul Richard Desmond in East London. The redevelopment, said to be worth £ billion, was approved in January by Mr Jenrick against the recommendation of a planning inspector. The local council in Tower Hamlets were set to introduce a Community Infrastructure Levythe day after Mr Jenrick stepped in and approved the plan. The levy would have obliged Mr Desmond to contribute at least £ million to support projects in the area. The decision was reversed after legal action by Tower Hamlets Council and Mr Jenrick accepted his decision was unlawful by reason of apparent bias. In heavily redacted emails released by Mr Jenrickaposs office tonight, officials discussed the Secretary of Stateaposs sense of urgency in granting the approval. In one email discussion, an unnamed Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government official wrote: On timing, my understanding is that [Mr Jenrick] is was insistent that decision issued this week ie tomorrow - as next week the viability of the scheme is impacted by a change in the London CIL regime. Another email reads: The appellant [Mr Desmond] believes that the proposal would not be viableliable to CIL charges. Text messages between Mr Jenrick and Mr Desmond reveal conversations between the pair after they had sat at the same table at a Tory fundraiser. Arranging a site visit to view the development, Mr Desmond wrote: We appreciate the speed as we donapost want to give Marxists loads of doe for nothing. In reply, Mr Jenrick warned Mr Desmond it was important not to give any appearance of being influenced by applicants of cases that I may have a role in or to have predetermined them and so I think it is best that we donapost meet until after the matter has decided. In a later text message to which Mr Jenrick did not reply, Mr Desmond explicitly told the minister the urgency in having the development approved was to save money in taxes. Mr Desmond wrote: We have to get the approval before January  otherwise payment of  million pounds to Tower Hamlets, meaning we have to stop and reduce social housing. Thanks Robert, look forward to speaking soon, Best, Richard. According to the documents, the March site visit did not take place and no further communication followed because Mr Jenrick did not take Mr Desmondaposs  calls when he attempted to get in contact on a number of occasions. Thereaposs no record in any of the documents of Mr Jenrickaposs department taking an interest in the deal prior to the Minister and Mr Jenrick sitting at the same table at a Tory dinner in November . Mr Jenrick was the first to make written contact with Mr Desmond, sending a text after the event which read: Good to spend time with you tonight, Richard. See you again soon I hope. Mr Jenrick insisted the row over his involvement in the Westferry Printworks planning decision was politically motivated. But he agreed to release documents and correspondence relating to the decision in accordance with Freedom of Information rules. He said he would release all relevant information relating to the planning decision later today.It came after Labour warned the row had blown apart confidence in the planning system.Shadow communities secretary Steve Reed told the Commons: The only way to put that right is for the Secretary of State to publish the evidence about what really happened. If heaposs done nothing wrong then heaposs got nothing to fear. So I hope he will welcome this opportunity to restore trust in a sector that will be so critical in rebuilding Britain after the lockdown. Mr Jenrick told MPs: I will write to the chair of the select committee outlining the timeline of events and the rationale for my decision-making pertaining to the Westferry Printworks planning decision. Alongside this letter, and after a comprehensive review of what documents might be in scope of this motion, and of the letter that he sent me on behalf of his select committee, I will be releasing later today all relevant information relating to this planning matter using the Freedom of Information Act as a benchmark.

title: black britain woman 83 tells
story: NewsBlack Britain: Woman, , tells how black pensioners couldnt earn enough to saveEllen Lebethe cries “solidarity” with the Black Lives Matter protesters who have taken to the streets across the world, after attending “every single anti-apartheid march” she could in her younger daysShareCommentsByNaimah Archibald-Powell:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHaving lived half her le in apartheid South Africa then half in the UK, Ellen Lebethe knows all about discrimination. She cries “solidarity” with the Black Lives Matter protesters who have taken to the streets across the world, after attending “every single anti-apartheid march” she could in her younger days. Now , much of her energy is spent fighting for the rights of the older generation with the Lambeth Pensioners Action Group and as a vice president of the National Pensioners Convention. Social care problems, low pensions and loneliness can affect all older people but, she says, inequality means black pensioners face even more disadvantage. Ellen says: “The British pension is one of the lowest in the developed world. As far as black pensioners are concerned, not only are they affected by a very poor pension, many of us occupied jobs which were classied as low-skilled – we didn’t earn an amount of money where we could put away for a rainy day or have savings, so we’re less well off than others.” Housing is a particular problem, “Most of us live on very poor estates and because we didn’t have much money, we’re not able to shop at Waitrose, we go down to Brixton Market or we go down the road to Lidl,” she says “Many of us live in cold, damp and poorly insulated housing and we are suffering illness as a result of that.” In addition, diabetes, high blood pressure, arthritis and high cholesterol are among the ailments that affect black communities disproportionately, making le as a black pensioner especially hard. But Ellen is also a passionate campaigner on issues that affect all pensioners, especially the broken promise that the TV license would be funded for the over-s, which the Mirror is campaigning over strongly. “For older people, especially the poor ones, it’s a lot of money,” Ellen says. “There are many of us who can’t leave our homes. In winter especially, we don’t leave our homes. Now with Covid-, we are scared to leave our homes. Some of us who live on our own are really lonely and the TV is the only company. It talks to us and some of us talk to the TV! “Sometimes when I watch Newsnight or a documentary, I speak to them, I challenge them. I know they can’t hear me.”  Ellen is proud of her South African heritage and belonging to the Sotho tribe. African artwork adorns the walls of her South London home, and her CD rack is stacked high with music from some of the most prolic black artists such as Nina Simone, as well as jazz compilations and several reggae albums. My own music collection embraces my black heritage too. I grew up on soulful RB, reggae and classic hip-hop. Now, I find myself drawn to dancehall, grime and rap – perhaps looking for the same voices, sense of belonging and retellings of my realities that older generations found in Nina Simone and Bob Marley. But as someone who is more than  years her junior, and born and raised in London, the idea of anything other than multiculturalism is dficult to imagine. So Ellen tells of growing up in Cape Town: “There’s a beautul mountain, Table Mountain. I was born at the little bit overlooking the ocean.”  Now, South Africa is associated with fine wines, cricket, and safari tourism, but for Ellen and many other South Africans, the scars of growing up under apartheid are not forgotten. During her youth, it was always evident where society placed her and people who looked like her, even in simple things like a trip to the beach. “It was segregated – ours was just the rocks and the sand. The white side had the restaurants, changing rooms. They had spaces where the children could play, with swings. The recreational facilities were not ours so we knew we were dferent.” Under apartheid, schools for non-whites were underfunded. You lived with the people who looked like you, and you all shared similar experiences – usually of deprivation and poverty. A quota system at universities meant they “only allowed a certain number of black students into each faculty”. But Ellen took a degree in English with her fees funded by her mother’s employer.  “My mother couldn’t afford to send me to university,” Ellen says. “My father died when I was . My mother cleaned the homes of rich white people and they paid my university fees.” She became a teacher and in  she moved to the UK – which she has called home ever since. Explaining how black identity is dferent in the two countries, she says: “Blackness in South Africa is part of the colonial history. The blackness here, it is us coming in, rather than us being born here.” This “otherness” underlies many of Britain’s race relations issues, she says. Ellen recalls an incident during her time as a teacher that proved to her that racism is taught – and, perhaps, can also be unlearned. She says: “You’re not born a racist. Your experience of racism is what is imposed on you. Those kids just saw me as Ms Lebethe. A good example is when we went to France. We got to Dover and I had to get off the bus to have my passport checked. They had a group passport and they were all British, I was still on my South African passport so I had a visa.  “One of the kids said to me, ‘Miss, why do you have to get off of the bus ’ and I said, ‘I have to have my passport checked because I’m a South African, I’m not British’. The kid said to me, ‘But you’re our miss. How can you be dferent ’” Ellen taught at several schools across the capital including in Tottenham, North London, where she observed the Broadwater Farm Riots, sparked by injustices at the hands of the police. Of the current protests, she says: “This isn’t new – George Floyd has just blown it wide open. It’s been brought to the fore quite vividly not only by his death but the response to his death.”

Jess Jackson, described as a beautul lady and a massive character, lost her two-year battle with the disease on June  leaving behind her three young children Max, seven Leo, six and Jenson, three. Her heartbroken mother Lynda Gilling has made an emotional appeal to other young women to make sure they attend their cervical screening appointments. Lynda said: My daughter knew what she wanted in le. She loved doing things with her three children outdoors, like taking them to the park. They were her world. Jess, who lived in Rumney, Cardf, first noticed typical signs of cervical cancer - which can include unusual bleeding and pelvic pain - at the age of just . After tests were carried out in hospital, it was confirmed that the disease was present. I was shocked more than anything . She was so young to have cancer. It was heartbreaking, added Lynda. Jess, fondly known to family members as aposJapos, then underwent several rounds of chemotherapy which her mum said made her sick and led to her losing her hair.  Despite making small signs of progress, in January this year the cancer was found to have spread to her stomach and lymph nodes and was deemed terminal. A GoFundMe page has now been set up by one of her close friends, Stacey-Marie Osborne, to pay for Jessapos funeral which is set to take place next month. Any money left over will be put into a bank account for her three boys, said Lynda. Friend Stacey-Marie Osborne added: Jess was a massive character and fought a very hard battle.  She was the type of friend you needed in your le to give you a straight, honest answer - and she did just that. She was very protective over her friends, but most importantly her three gorgeous boys who have now lost their mum to such a horrible disease. Jess was big, bold and beautul. The cancer never phased her and she never wanted sympathy, just love and kindness. Every year around  women are diagnosed with cervical cancer in Wales. It is the most common type of cancer in women under the age of .

title: hundreds line streets dunkirk hero
story: NewsHundreds line the streets as Dunkirk hero turns  after Covid- cancels partyA big party was planned to celebrate Eric Taylors th birthday but after it was cancelled because of the lockdown people lined the streets to mark his special dayShareByAdam Aspinall:,  JUN NewsEric Taylor celebrated his th birthday " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHundreds of people lined the streets as a Dunkirk hero turned , after his party was cancelled due to Covid-. Veteran Eric Taylor was treated to a military parade and fly-past, and a brass band as he enjoyed the festivities from his garden. Eric, of Helston, Cornwall, said: “I’m so pleased to reach this age and still able to enjoy what I’ve received, with everybody helping to make a tremendous day on my th birthday.” Sailors from the nearby RNAS Culdrose held a parade in Eric’s honour. Commander Martin Barlow presented Eric with a card from The Queen to mark his th birthday. He said: “On behalf of everyone at RNAS Culdrose, I’d like to wish Mr Taylor a very happy th birthday and I hope he has enjoyed this special day with his family and friends. “In this year, as we remember the th anniversary of the end of the Second World War, it is truly remarkable to think that Mr Taylor was  years old on VE Day. He is a direct link back to a time in our history that should never be forgotten. Eric was captured in Dunkirk at , with the Royal Norfolk Regiment.  He spent five years as a prisoner of war in Poland. He was later awarded the British Empire Medal for his services and featured in the Channel  documentary Dunkirk – The Forgotten Heroes, which was recently shown again on TV to mark the th anniversary of Dunkirk.

title: liam 4 needs one last

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA desperate family is facing a race against time to raise the money they need to send their sick son to the USA for a cancer vaccine. Little Liam Scott, aged four, from Sevenoaks, Kent, has been undergoing gruelling treatments for a rare cancer since he was diagnosed last summer. Neuroblastoma only affects around  children in the UK every year but while Liam is approaching the end of his treatment there is a high chance it couldmeaning time is of the essence. So his parents Claire, , and Mike, , are trying to raise a whopping £, to get him on a plane to New York by September where he can receive an experimental vaccine. Incredibly Liamaposs parents have already managed to raise £, but the coronavirus pandemic has cruelly hampered their fundraising leaving them just under £, short. Mum Claire said: “We are running out of time, to have come this far is unbelievable but we just need one last push.” Neuroblastoma is a cancer which forms in certain types of nerve tissue and the vast majority of cases occur in children under five-years-old but it is known to relapse. The vaccine on offer at New Yorkaposs world leading Sloan Kettering Center is known as a bivalent vaccine which medics hope will prevent the dreaded neuroblastoma from ing. The vaccine is licensed in the USA but not yet in Europe. The family learned the awful news about Liam last July just a day after Claire gave birth to his baby sister Kylie. But they have been tirelessly fundraising ever since.  Claire said: “Hearing he had cancer the day after you gave birth to his sister was incredibly tough, I had her in my arms when I was told and then Liam had to start treatment the very same day, so it has been incredibly tough for us ever since. “I can only describe finding out your son has cancer as pure pain and being broken beyond belief.” They were given an early boost in their fundraising efforts thanks to former Dagenham and Redbridge footballer Charlie Holmes whose daily runs for Liam on social media went viral.
